Gender: Male

Age: 67

MRN: 788449

Diagnosis: Hepatocellular Carcinoma

History and Physical:

Date: 31/07/2024

Patient: I've been feeling pain in my right upper abdominal area for about a week now. There's been

some  on-and-off  constipation,  and  I  had  a  fever  about  6-8  days  ago.  The  fever  reached  up  to

101-102Â°F  but  has  been  gone  for  the  past  2-3  days.  Also,  I've  noticed  some  weight  loss,  but  I

haven't really been able to track it accurately.

Doctor: I see. Let's go over your medical history. Do you have any chronic conditions?

Patient:  Yes,  I  have  diabetes  and  hypertension,  but  no  history  of  hepatitis.  I  haven't  had  any

surgeries before either.

Doctor: Got it. Ill take a look at your recent lab results. Here's what we have:

PIVKA: 20

AFP: 46.7

PSA: 0.8 (normal)

Bilirubin: 1.3

 Creatinine: 0.9

Hemoglobin (Hgb): 13.3

MCV: 83

WBC: 11.3

Platelets (Plt): 247

HbA1C: 6.8%

Patient: Okay, what do these results indicate?

Doctor:  Your  AFP  is  elevated,  which  is  concerning.  It's  associated  with  liver  issues,  like

hepatocellular  carcinoma  (HCC).  But  we  need  more  information.  Your  ultrasound  shows  a  solid

mass measuring 6.2 cm by 6.2 cm, along with an enlarged prostate.

Patient: What does this mean for me?

Doctor:  We  need  to  confirm  whether  this  mass  is  an  abscess  or  potentially  cancer.  Your  CT  scan

shows  a  7  x  6  cm  lesion  in  the  liver,  and  based  on  its  features,  we  are  concerned  about  evolving

hepatic  abscess  versus  metastatic  deposits.  Well  discuss  this  at  the  MDT  (multidisciplinary  team)

meeting on Friday.

Patient: Whats the plan moving forward?

 Doctor:  For  now,  well  submit  your  CD  for  review,  and  well  meet  again  on  Friday  after  the  MDT

discussion to decide the next steps. Well consider further tests and potential treatments.

Date: 07/08/2024

Patient: I havent had any active complaints since my last visit. No fever, and the pain has also been

manageable.

Doctor:  Thats  good  to  hear.  Lets  review  your  previous  scans  and  tests.  The  CT  scan  now  shows

that the lesion in your liver is likely an atypical HCC, with possible tumor thrombus in the portal vein.

The abscess is less likely. We should consider either TACE or systemic treatments. Ill refer you to

IR for further evaluation.

Patient: So, its still concerning?

Doctor: Yes, but well proceed carefully. Well have another MDT discussion on Friday to determine if

surgical  resection  might  be  an  option,  along  with  chemotherapy  or  locoregional  therapy.  Well  also

check your CA 19-9 levels for further clarity.

Date: 20/08/2024

Patient: What do the latest results show?

Doctor: Weve got the results from your fibroscan and viral screening. Your HBsAg, Anti-HCV, and

Anti-HIV  tests  all  came  back  non-reactive,  which  is  good.  Your  CA  19-9  is  normal  as  well.  The

fibroscan  indicates  that  you  have  an  F0  stage  of  hepatic  fibrosis,  meaning  there's  no  significant

fibrosis at this time. However, your tumor still requires further management.

 Patient: Whats the next step in treatment?

Doctor:  Well  continue  with  the  plan  to  refer  you  for  a  non-anatomical  resection  or  posterior

sectionectomy.  The  surgery  date  will  be  confirmed  soon.  Afterward,  we'll  begin  discussing

chemotherapy or immunotherapy options based on the latest research.

Date: 21/08/2024

Patient: What did the latest review indicate?

Doctor: Following the re-MDT discussion, we've decided to proceed with immunotherapy, given its

higher effectiveness, though it can be costly. Well review all available options closely and make sure

youre informed before moving forward.

Patient: Thank you. Whats next?

Doctor: Ill send you to meet with the oncology team to begin immunotherapy in the next two weeks.

Well also have you follow up in the HPB clinic to monitor your progress.

Date: 19/09/2024

Patient: Im feeling some weakness and drowsiness post-surgery. I also noticed some bleeding from

the wound site. Should I be concerned?

Doctor: Its important that we monitor this closely. The wound is healing well, but the bleeding and

other symptoms like weakness will need to be evaluated. Well review your lab results:

 Hb: 10.7

WBC: 9.05

Platelets: 431

Total Bilirubin: 0.56

Direct Bilirubin: 0.27

ALT/AST: 93/34

Albumin: 3.67

Creatinine: 0.84

AFP: 46.7 (same as previous)

Doctor:  It  seems  like  your  liver  function  is  improving,  but  well  need  to  continue  monitoring  your

condition closely, especially after the wedge resection. The histopathology report indicates a grade

3 tumor with vascular invasion. The oncology team will help determine the best course of treatment

from here.

Date: 16/10/2024

Patient: Hows my recovery going?

 Doctor: Your recovery seems to be progressing well. Youre at day 36 post-surgery. The tumor was

poorly differentiated, and there was vascular invasion present. However, there was no malignancy

found  in  the  lymph  nodes.  You  still  need  follow-up  care,  and  chemotherapy  or  immunotherapy  is

recommended for further treatment.

Patient: What should I do next?

Doctor:  Ill  have  you  continue  follow-up  visits,  and  we'll  proceed  with  the  treatment  plan  based  on

your histopathology report. Youll also need to follow up with oncology to discuss the next steps for

treatment.

ActiveSymptoms: pain in right upper abdominal area
NegativeFindings: no malignancy found in lymph nodes

DiagnosticConclusions: elevated AFP associated with liver issues
solid mass in liver likely atypical HCC
possible tumor thrombus in portal vein

ImagingFindings: solid mass measuring 6.2 cm by 6.2 cm
fibroscan indicating F0 stage of hepatic fibrosis

NextAppointmentDetails: next appointment in two weeks for immunotherapy

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient presented with abdominal pain and fever, diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma, underwent surgery, and is recovering.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Initial tests indicated elevated AFP and imaging showed liver lesions, leading to further evaluations and a diagnosis of atypical HCC.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Post-surgery recovery is ongoing, with plans for immunotherapy based on histopathology results.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Monitoring for symptoms post-surgery and evaluating the effectiveness of the treatment plan.
